body:
I also followed the instructions under "Python" and "Node.js" on this page: https://doccano.github.io/doccano/getting-started/ 
With this I can login, create a project, import data, create labels on the  http://127.0.0.1:3000/ URL, but when I click   "Start Annotation" I get a 404 error for the URL http://127.0.0.1:3000/projects/1/text-classification?page=1 and the console of the Python server shows the following:
```
[02/Feb/2021 19:57:40] "GET /v1/projects/1/labels HTTP/1.1" 200 433
[02/Feb/2021 19:57:40] "GET /v1/projects/1/docs?limit=10&offset=0&q=&doc_annotations__isnull= HTTP/1.1" 200 879
```

The following workflow will be useful for you. It publishes doccano as a Python package.
https://github.com/doccano/doccano/blob/master/.github/workflows/pypi-publish.yml

If you want to `pip install`, you need to build the frontend and move the result to `app/client/`

Thank you a lot for that! I start completely fresh (new cloned repo) on Ubuntu 18.04 using a fresh conda environment with Python 3.8.5 and carried out these commands
```
cd doccano
mkdir app/client
nvm install 12.1
nvm use 12.1
npm install --global yarn
cd frontend
export PUBLIC_PATH=/static/_nuxt/
yarn install
yarn build
cp -r dist ../app/client/
cd  ../app
python -m pip install --upgrade pip
pip install pipenv
pipenv sync --dev
pipenv run collectstatic
cd ..
pip install -e .
```

Running `doccano` after this works! 

I also tried to run it using gunicorn with these commands:
```
cd app 
python manage.py wait_for_db
python manage.py migrate
python manage.py create_roles
python manage.py create_admin --username admin --password password  --email someone@somewhere.me --noinput
gunicorn --bind="0.0.0.0:8000" --workers=4 app.wsgi --timeout 300
```

This initially gave me an exception: `ImportError: No module named django.core.wsgi`
It seems this was caused by the existence of /usr/local/bin/gunicorn apparently.
I removed that file and made sure gunicorn is also installed into the conda environment i use, then retried. 

Everything seems to work fine now!

issue.title: No way to restrict text classification labels to exactly one label to assign

repository.name: doccano
repository.description: Open source annotation tool for machine learning practitioners.

issue.body:
Most classification tasks require exactly one label for each instance. This is also true for most text classification tasks, for example with sentiment classificaiton, and the possible labels negative, neutral, positive, each instance should receive one of the three labels, assigning e.g. both neutral and positive would make not sense.

Yet the text classification task in doccano still does not allow to restrict assignment to a single label, annotators are free to assign as many labels as they want, including all of them!

This limits the use of doccano for text classification tasks rather severely. The option to allow for any number of labels (0 to all of them) would still be good to have for multilabel classification tasks (e.g. assigning topics), but that is a much rarer annotation task in general.

body:
So far for me the steps above seem to do everything I need. 
Maybe put them into the docs somewhere for others or put them into a file to be run if needed?
Otherwise and if nobody finds a flaw in those steps I think this issue can be closed.

issue.title: [Question] on pip installation... files and configuration

repository.name: doccano
repository.description: Open source annotation tool for machine learning practitioners.

issue.body:
On pip installation, which files does doccano create? Where db is stored?

How to set up admin user and password?

I don't see this in readme...

issue.title: Getting errors during annotations, missing labels

```
django.db.utils.IntegrityError: UNIQUE constraint failed: api_documentannotation.document_id, api_documentannotation.user_id, api_documentannotation.label_id
```
And the GUI is sometimes showing popup dialogs mentioning a server 500 error. 

What is more worrying is that after assigning a label to an example and moving on to other examples, some of the examples then do not have any label, so the annotation was unsuccessful, but this was not directly visible in the GUI. 

This happens *sometimes* so it is hard to find out what could cause this. 

I have installed doccano from git, commit 8d6d41f85adef4f80d21fdcbd4e07561ac74cd  and I am using the patch from https://github.com/doccano/doccano/issues/1191

I am running doccano using Python 3.8.5 
```
gunicorn --bind="0.0.0.0:8000" --workers=4 app.wsgi --timeout 300
```
in the app subdirectory after setting up pretty much like in https://github.com/doccano/doccano/issues/1192 

Does Doccano have a problem running with several workers using gunicorn?
